title: COMP/STAT112 Notebook
text:
Introduction
This is my online notebook for COMP/STAT112 course taken at Macalester College. Please, use the side bar on the left for navigation.

title: 4  Introductory Reading Notes 9/6/24
text:
The intention behind data science is to use data to understand information relating to a specific field of study and question, within a specific and defined context.
Within RStudio we have access to a console (for quick calculations and testing code), our console history to access previous work, as well as files and plot packages to support our endeavors on R.
Quarto is a technological tool incorporated into RStudio to enable the reproducible creation of nicely formatted documents, webpages, etc.
It is important to leave comments (#) as you work for your own clarity and understanding, as well as for that of others. You want to be able to look back on your work and know what you were thinking /doing at past moments, and you also want others to be able to look at your work and know what you were doing. Leaving comments on your work is good for communication.

title: 5  Chapter 1 Reading Notes: (Univariate) Data Visualization
text:
Why data visualization is beneficial:

Provides a sense of scale and typical outcomes
Provides information about typical outliers
Provides an understanding of patterns and relationships between variables
Informs the next step of our analysis
Prompts us to refine our investigative question
Supports and communicates findings gained by analyzing data

Data visualization is the process of mapping data to different plot components
Mapping components in data visualization: (1) A frame or coordinate system – variables /features that define the axes and gridlines of the canvas (2) A layer: geometric elements (such as lines and/or points) added to the canvas to represent the data or patterns in the data - Each geometric element is a separate layer and there can be many (3) Scales: geometric elements can tell us more about the potential scaling and grouping of data (4) Faceting: splitting of data into multiple subplots to examine different groups within the data (5) Theme: additional controls relating to the aesthetics of the plot
“gg” = grammar of graphics

title: 6  Chapter 2 Reading Notes: Bivariate Visualization
text:
How to set up a plot:

set up a frame
add a layer / geometric element
change the theme, e.g. axis labels, color, fill

Bar charts count up the number of observations of each outcome of a variable. 

Good for categorical variables

Histograms count up the number of observations that fall into different numerical ranges of variables

Good for quantitative variables

Univariate plots study one variable at a time
Response variable: the variable whose variability we would like to explain 
Predictors: variables that might explain some of the variability in the response 
Relationship trend: direction and form
Relationship strength: variability from the trend
Outliers in variability 
Quantitative variables

require a new axis (or a quantitative scale if we run out of axes).

Categorical variables require a new way to "group" the graphic 

eg: using colors, shapes, separate facets, etc

title: 7  Chapter 3 Reading Notes: Multivariate Viz
text:
Scales change the color, fill, size, shape, or other properties according to the levels of a new variable. 
A dendrogram is a type of diagram that shows the extent of the existing relationship between objects or entities using branches
Some data visualization techniques that indicate the relative scale of each variable:

Heat maps 
Star plot

Each star represents an individual observation
Communicates to us what variables are dominant within a data set

title: 8  Chapter 4 Reading Notes: Spatial Viz
text:
Simpson's Paradox
Confounding variable

Influences both the dependent and independent variable

 Omitted variable 

Relevant variable that is not included in the model




Lurking variable

Not included in the analysis, but can affect the outcome of the analysis 


Types of spatial viz:

Point Maps: plotting locations of individual observations (ex: bigfoot sightings)
Contour Maps: plotting the density or distribution of observations (not the individual observations themselves)
Choropleth Maps: plotting outcomes in different regions




Spatial maps can be static or dynamic/interactive.
To make a map, the data set requires:

location coordinates for your points of interest (for point maps); or
variable outcomes for your regions of interest (for choropleth maps)

The boundaries of our map are determined by latitude and longitude coordinates
addProviderTiles() changes the base map.

Typing Providers into the console gives you a list of different possible base maps to choose from

addMarkers() and addCircles() are used to mark locations. 

Typing ?addControl into the console summarizes marker aesthetics and directs you on how to change them

To change the thickness of lines points and pixels: weight 
To change the transparency: opacity (does the same thing as setting alpha= but is specific to this package)


To specify color: color=col2hex("name of color")
Point maps can be made using either the leaflet() package or the ggplot() package

leaflet() is better for interactive maps, but ggplot() is better for efficient map making
